metadata.title: Laryngectomy, Partial(1)
anatomical location body part affected: Larynx; laryngeal muscles; laryngeal nerves; laryngeal cartilages
area of specialty: v oice and v oice disorders
description: As an alternative to total laryngectomy, partial laryngectomy is the excision of parts of the larynx as a treatment for laryngeal and pharyngeal cancer.(1) Which parts of the larynx are excised depends on the type, location, and extent of the cancer present
For detailed information on total laryngectomy, see Clinical Review…Laryngectomy, Total ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708744

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Following partial laryngectomy, a patient can present with any number of symptoms due to the physical and anatomical changes resulting from surgery.(1) One result of most types of partial laryngectomy is dysphonia.(1) If chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy was also used to treat the cancer, the patient may present with edema, inflammation of the remaining laryngeal tissues/muscles, xerostomia (dry mouth), stiffness of the muscles and tissues, and/or increased phlegm.(1,2,3) The most common diagnoses following partial laryngectomy are dysphonia and dysphagia(1,2,3) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Because of the social and psychological effects of partial laryngectomy (due to the potential loss of communication), an SLP should be involved in the case during the preoperative stage to help prepare the patient and/or family for the future rehabilitative process(1,3,6)
An entire speech and swallowing examination should be performed before AND after partial laryngectomy to promote success of speech therapy postoperatively(1,3,6)

The surgeon should have a comprehensive discussion with the patient and his or her family prior to surgery so that the patient is prepared for the significant lifestyle changes that result from surgery(1,3)

It is also important for the SLP to set realistic goals with the patient and his or her family prior to surgery to ensure that they understand the difference between the patient’s presurgical “normal” voice and the “functional” voice he or she will gain during therapy(1)

causes: Currently, partial laryngectomy, near-total  laryngectomy, and chemoradiation of the larynx are performed as“organ-preservation” treatments for laryngeal and pharyngeal cancer(1,2,3)
pathogenesis: Partial laryngectomy is performed when a surgeon feels that it is possible to effectively treat laryngeal cancer while stillpreserving enough of the larynx for functional voicing and swallowing(1,2,3)–Vertical partial laryngectomy is indicated in the case of T1-staged  cancer of the true vocal fold that is isolated in themiddle third of the cord and the vocal cord free margin(1)–Frontolateral vertical partial laryngectomy is indicated in the case of glottic tumors that extend to arytenoids, laryngealventricle, or anterior commissure(1)-In a 10-year  retrospective chart review study conducted in China with 58 patients who underwent frontolateral verticalpartial laryngectomy, researchers found that, compared to other treatments, this type of surgery provided efficient localcontrol of the cancer with few, minor postoperative complications and good postoperative vocal quality(17)-In some cases of frontolateral vertical partial laryngectomy, the surgeon may use titanium mesh as means ofreconstructing the laryngeal framework to provide structural support and to maintain airway patency(4)-It is possible for the surgeon to reconstruct and/or medialize the vocal fold during or after a vertical partial laryngectomyto improve vocal fold closure for voicing. Although this might improve functional voice production after partiallaryngectomy, the voice will not sound exactly as it did prior to surgery(24)–Vertical hemilaryngectomy is indicated in stage T1 and T2 glottic tumors and glottic tumors that extend to the false vocalcords(1)-Most patients who undergo hemilaryngectomy are able to return to a regular oral diet and have functional swallowingability soon after surgery. Patients who required extended hemilaryngectomy with excision of parts of the arytenoidshave increased risk of dysphagia(16)–Supraglottic horizontal hemilaryngectomy is indicated in T1-,T2-,  and T3-staged  supraglottic tumors.(1)All structuresabove the true vocal folds are removed in this type of surgery(16)-Patients who have undergone supraglottic laryngectomy typically experience oropharyngeal dysphagia characterizedby recurrent aspiration because the only structures to protect the airway are the true vocal folds (as well as at least onearytenoid)(16)-In addition to removal of a considerable amount of the larynx, there is often damage to the internal branch of thesuperior laryngeal nerve, which can result in impaired sensation of the remaining laryngeal structures, furthercompromising swallowing safety(16)–Supracricoid partial laryngectomy is indicated in glottic tumors involving both true vocal folds and tumors that extendinto the subglottis and laryngeal ventricle. (1) For this type of surgery, the cricoid, hyoid, and one mobile arytenoidremain; the epiglottis is sometimes excised depending on the extent of the tumor(16)-Patients who have undergone supracricoid partial laryngectomy with the excision of the epiglottis are at high risk foraspiration due to minimal airway protection(16)–Near-total  laryngectomy is indicated for laryngeal tumors that have extended past the boundaries of the more conservativepartial laryngectomy surgeries; however, the midline posterior glottis, midline postcricoid region, ipsilateral posteriorone-half  to two-thirds  of the vocal cord, and ipsilateral subglottis must NOT be involved(2)
For minimally invasive cancers of the vocal folds and larynx, chemotherapy, radiation, and/or endoscopic resection withmicrosurgical instruments or lasers may be indicated(3)
risk factors for laryngeal cancer: Male sex(21,22)–The American Cancer Society’s estimates that there will be 13,360 new cases of laryngeal cancer in the United States in2017. Of those cases, 10,570 will occur in men and 2,790 in women(21)
Cigarette smoking is the biggest risk factor for laryngeal cancer(2,22)–Risk of developing laryngeal cancer is considerably increased when smoking is combined with heavy consumption ofalcohol(2,22)
Genetic syndromes (specifically Fanconi anemia and Dyskeratosis congenital)(22)
Prolonged and extensive occupational exposure to wood dust, paint fumes, and chemicals(22)
Race (highest risk associated with African Americans)(22)

overall contraindications precautions: Intensive speech therapy for patients following partial laryngectomy should not begin until internal sutures have healed; this process takes anywhere from 2 days to 2 weeks(1)

It is important for the rehabilitation team, including the surgeon, speech-language  pathologist (SLP), nurses, oncologist, radiation oncologist, nutritionist, dentist, and potentially a psychiatrist or psychiatric nurse, to develop relationships with the patient in the preoperative phase in order to maximize gains from postoperative therapy(1,3,6)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Document the type of partial laryngectomy performed Document where the patient is in the course of cancer treatment (e.g., completed treatment, just beginning treatment). Note whether the patient has received radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or both Patients with persistent aspiration following partial laryngectomy might benefit from injection of collagen into the arytenoids to reduce aspiration during swallowing(7)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Document results of any diagnostic tests that have been completed, including swallowing
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: The treatments for a patient’s cancer (e.g., chemotherapy and radiation therapy) can cause or aggravate existing symptoms such as pain, xerostomia, swelling, altered taste and sensation, thick saliva, reflux, lymphedema, and poor oral hygiene(16) -It is important to consider the time that has lapsed since the patient’s most recent chemotherapy or radiation treatment as the pain is often greater immediately following these treatments -Patients might wish to stop all oral intake and dysphagia exercises during courses of radiation therapy because of pain; however, this can cause increased stiffness and immobility of the swallowing mechanism(16)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms, which may include assessment of secretions and secretion management from stoma (if present),(2) pulmonary function, and changes in salivation/xerostomia(1)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: The patient may or may not require supplemental oxygen; does the patient have difficulty breathing through the stoma? Does the patient have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)? COPD can affect the patient’s voice due to limited airflow(1)Note psychosocial status -Patients who have undergone partial laryngectomy are at increased risk for social and psychological problems due to the loss or alteration of communication ability(1,3,6) -Authors of a study conducted in Turkey compared differences in quality of life and psychosocial status among 108 individuals who underwent either total or partial laryngectomy. Scores on the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30) indicated much better overall quality of life and global health status among those individuals with partial laryngectomy. Additionally, although present in individuals with both types of surgery, depression, anxiety, and sexual dysfunction was much more prevalent among those individuals with total laryngectomy(25) -Post-operative  dysphagia is associated with significantly reduced quality of life in patients who have undergone partial laryngectomy.(20) It is essential to monitor both swallowing function as well as patient-reported  quality of life during the immediate post-operative  phase to ensure early and adequate intervention is received(20) -Complete a quality of life assessment -V oice Handicap Index (VHI)(3,8)validated instrument for assessing quality of life in patients with head and neck cancer. The four domains assessed with this instrument are communication, eating, emotion, and pain(13,19)An outcome measure that includes patient self-ratings  of quality of life due to swallowing and eating ability(20)A questionnaire designed to assess the quality of life of patients with cancer; there is a subtest for head and neck cancer patients(20) -Document signs of depression, anxiety, or other psychosocial disturbance and refer to mental health professional as appropriateNote hearing status -Does the patient have known hearing loss? If so, does he or she wear hearing aids? past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior history of laryngeal surgery?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, other cancers, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing (e.g., dry mouth, dysphagia) A laryngocele can occur as a complication of a superior partial laryngectomy(9) Laryngocele is a cystic lesion that results from upward dilatation of the laryngeal saccule with entrapped air(9) Symptoms include cervical mass, shortness of breath, and fever(9)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient's speech impact his or her ability to participate in professional or leisure activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: With whom does the patient normally communicate? Does the patient require use of the telephone for work or other social situations?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers; identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? What languages are used in the home, and how often does the patient speak in each language?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess the patient’s functional lung volumes during voice assessment
relevant tests and measures.posture: Poor posture can affect breath support for voicing(1,2,3) –If indicated refer patient for an occupational and/or physical therapy evaluation to increase good posture for voice production/respiratory support
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: It is important to review surgical reports to determine how much of the larynx was removed as well as the manner in which the larynx/pharynx has been reconstructed(1,2,3)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Assess the patient’s current ability to communicate, including writing with pen/paper or electronic device, as well as his or her stimulability for esophageal speech when appropriateAssess speech production and articulation skills; document speech intelligibility -At this time in the evaluation, it could be appropriate to introduce an artificial larynx for patients with severe aphonia following partial laryngectomy. For detailed information on treatment using an artificial larynx, see Clinical Review…T708920Patients will likely have some degree of dysphonia following partial laryngectomy(1,2,3) -Assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance -For detailed information on assessment of the voice and dysphonia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: It is important to assess cognitive abilities in partial laryngectomy patients in order to determine the most appropriate voice substitution method(1)
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Complete swallowing assessment per physician orders; patients who have undergone partial laryngectomy are at increased risk for dysphagia and aspiration, especially silent aspiration(10,11,12)T709050
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: Tracheostomy tubes are common in the few days and sometimes weeks after a partial laryngectomy because of edema in the airway.(16) If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Following partial laryngectomy, patients might experience hypersensitivity due to edema or swelling; vocal exercise should only begin once the pain subsides and the patient has received approval from his or her surgeon.(1) Treatment often begins approximately 2 weeks postsurgery; refer to physician orders for information on each specific patient

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Following an evaluation, the SLP and the patient must decide together on the best course of treatment.(1,2,3) The most common diagnoses following partial laryngectomy are dysphonia and dysphagia(1,2,3)
prognosis: In a study conducted in France with 24 patients who underwent partial frontolateral laryngectomies, researchers investigated which preoperative factors appeared to influence swallowing outcomes postsurgery. Swallow function of each patient was evaluated via both FEES and VFSS evaluation at 15 days and 2 months after the partial laryngectomy. Twenty of the patients were able to have food and liquid by mouth for all or part of their nutritional intake at the time of discharge from the hospital; by 2 months postsurgery, 21 patients were eating exclusively by mouth, and only 1 patient still had a gastrostomy tube at a 6-month  follow-up.  In this study, the two factors that appeared to relate to postoperative swallowing function were T stage (i.e., tumor size) and length of hospital stay (longer stays for those with poorer swallowing scores on early assessment)(15)

In a study conducted in Italy with 32 patients who underwent supracricoid or supraglottic partial laryngectomy, researchers found no significant difference in outcomes of swallow between the two types of laryngectomy. In this study, the only factor that was significantly correlated to poorer swallowing outcomes was radiation therapy(18)

In a study conducted in China with 30 patients who had undergone total laryngectomy and 60 patients who had undergone a conservation partial laryngectomy, researchers investigated the outcomes of a multi-modality  comprehensive intervention.(19) Comprehensive management included a combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy individualized to patient’s cancer and medical status. Immediately postintervention and then again after a period of 47 months, researchers assessed quality of life and laryngeal function (i.e., speech, swallowing, breathing abilities). A total of 45 patients who had undergone partial laryngectomy survived to followup, and in this group 41/45 had intelligible speech. Of the group of 45 surviving patients who had undergone partial laryngectomy, 44/45 underwent tracheostomy during surgery and 38/44 had been decannulated. None of the patients required any type of feeding tube after 3 months postintervention, but the majority (~70%) of patients, in both total and partial laryngectomy groups, reported mild to moderate xerostomia. None of the patients reported moderate to severe dyspnea at follow-up  indicating good respiratory outcomes(19)

Authors of a retrospective case series conducted in the United States with 3 patients who underwent partial laryngectomy and radiation therapy for laryngeal cancer reported that late onset dysphagia occurred in all 3 patients. Despite having a functional swallow without aspiration for between 11 and 15 years, all of these patients eventually developed dysphagia with aspiration and recurrent pneumonia. Most studies on partial laryngectomy and dysphagia measure outcomes in the short term; patients should be educated that late onset dysphagia is a possible outcome of partial laryngectomy(23)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: If signs of depression or grieving are noted, a referral should be made to psychology or psychiatry.(6) In the case of complete aphonia that persists for 4-6 months, refer the patient to his or her ENT surgeon.(2) Refer immediately to physician if the patient has difficulty breathing; refer to nutritionist in the case of dysphagia to ensure proper caloric intake(16)
treatment summary: Dysphagia therapy : Dysphagia therapy for patients who have undergone partial laryngectomy will include both compensatory and rehabilitative techniques. Compensatory techniques include maneuvers and postures to increase airway protection (e.g., supraglottic swallow, head rotation) as well as diet modifications.(16) Rehabilitative exercises will focus on increasing the strength of the remaining laryngeal structures and muscles. For detailed information on dysphagia therapy, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic(16)

Voice exercises:  The following exercises improve the voice in most cases; however, overall improvement will depend on type and location of the tumor as well as how the larynx was reconstructed following surgery(1) –Forced adduction exercises -Teaching the patient to bring the vocal cords and other remaining structures closer to midline using breath holds, pushing or pulling(1)  -ONLY to be performed while patient is doing exercises and NOT while patient is speaking to avoid developing overcompensation habits(1) -In addition to improving vocal fold closure for phonation, adduction exercises promote improved airway protection during swallowing(16) –V ocal function exercises(3) -Improve coordination and vocal fold endurance -Involve a warm-up,  stretching and contracting the vocal folds and strengthening the cords by sustaining pitches

Smith accent technique:  A holistic treatment method that teaches the patient to increase breath support, relaxation of the throat, and rhythm of speech.(3) Emphasis on utilization of the mouth, nose, and bones of the face to increase resonance of the voice(3) ›For detailed information on treatment techniques, see the series of Clinical Reviews on dysphagia and dysphonia as well as Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Patients with Head and Neck Cancer , referenced above . maintenance or prevention: As partial laryngectomy is a treatment for advanced laryngeal cancer; prevention of partial laryngectomy is synonymous with prevention of laryngeal cancer and/or detection and treatment of laryngeal cancer in the earlier stages to avoid need for surgery Studies have demonstrated a clear link between cigarette smoking and laryngeal cancer(5) Heavy smoking in combination with heavy use of alcohol greatly increases the risk of laryngeal cancer(5,6)
patient education: Patient education for patients before and after partial laryngectomy is very important due to the significant life changes that occur following this procedure Studies have shown that early intervention, including preoperative education, results in the best outcomes(1,2,3) Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
